comments.commentBody:
If only Galileo and Leonardo were here today. One can only imagine their reactions to seeing not merely a speck of light in the night sky but a view from as close by as 7600 miles --from Bergen Norway to the tip of Chile.
Probably man's greatest achievement and likely the least appreciated by people the world over. Celebrations like this bring on the clicks but by next week, it will be back to what celebrity is wearing the least amount of clothing.
The other sad thing is that these dedicated people earn in a year what some basketball player earns in week or two--and contributions to humankind 9 billion miles apart.
sadly, all they will get from congress in the next budget year is a LUMP OF COAL.

In this world full of conflict, strife, and general backwardness, sometimes the news feels like little more than a depressing chronicling of mankind's march to its inevitable destruction. It's refreshing to occasionally be reminded that humanity is capable of some breathtakingly awesome stuff, too. Well done, NASA.

@Dwayne Moholitny: "CTombaughs' discoveries far outweigh anything anyone alive has ever contributed to astronomy ..."

This sounds like a troll, and Clyde Tombaugh deserves credit for discovering Pluto and numerous other objects, but there are far more significant discoveries by "anyone alive". Three in chronological order:

1. Cosmic microwave background.
2. Pulsars.
3. Exoplanets.

From my understanding, ClydeTombaugh rallied against Pluto being declassified as a dwarf planet his entire life & to commemorate his contribution to our universe by demoting Pluto nine years after his death speaks volumes as to the jealousy that abounds behind the glad handing & goofy grins. Although his wife diplomatically skirts the issue stating her deceased husband would have accepted the vote, I find that hard to believe. CTombaughs' discoveries far outweigh anything anyone alive has ever contributed to astronomy & it's disrespectful for those sitting at IAU headquarters to simultaneously shake his hand & slap his face at the same time; hopefully, future astronomers will rectify the myopic nature of the current crop of scientists who celebrate naming spots & colorizing photos as their contribution to space exploration.
Are you serious?  Obama is busily rallying liberals and war opponents to try to fend off opposition.  They and the Syrians are the only ones who fully support this deal.

Interesting that two amazing human feats should be celebrated on the same day, one 3.6 billion miles away near our now much less mysterious neighbor Pluto and the other across a conference table showing that human beings can perhaps live together peaceably on our planet and control our science.. Perhaps even Iran is a little less strange to us today.

The Pluto mission and the Iran nuclear agreement both have their neigh sayers who base their opinions on their fears that we can not trust each other or that we do not have enough resources for our greatest explorations, but how can we justify our existence unless we reach out to discover new worlds and possible realities.

But does it help people's lives? For all the wonderfulness of it and the excitement, I'm not sure how it does. It helps us connect with and understand the awesome infinitely huge universe we exist in, and having that perspective is worth something, probably a lot
if it helps people feel excited about something, if even for a short while, doesn't that help people?

I admire how people can work together to create something as magnificent as the New Horizon spacecraft to explore something as magnificent as our universe.  Congratulations to everybody involve in the project and it is good too see that for once they took money from our taxes to build something that does not destroy people's lives.
President Obama tweeted out that "Pluto just had its first visitor!"  Maybe.

I am a newbie in space adventures, having only recently become an ardent fan of Neil Degrasse Tyson and all the science programs on "Discovery Science" and "National Geographic". I am getting goose bumps reading about Pluto and other fans' comments. I cannot wait to go back to the Rose Center. Go NASA!

GKK, Singapore

Am sorry. I can't help it. But I just had to say somethin', even at the risk of incurring the wrath of the world, and even if this comment has nuthin' to do with science/astronomy: but to me, it seems that saying that something like hip-hop is of "African" origen is -absolutely- nothing to brag about...

Maybe a few centuries from now, IF it will be possible for a human being(s) to write the history of music from a truly objective, impartial viewpoint, the appearance of hip-hop will have to be considered the worst thing to happen to music in, well... the history of music. I can HEAR it: Hip-hop is just sounds and noises made by people sampling and using computer software. It does NOT entail the same level of brainwork as people composing melodies from scratch (Chopin, George Gershwin, James Brown, etc. etc). In fact, it allows people to make "recordings" with minimal or NO brainwork -and minimal or NO talent. Rapping is NOT the same as singing: Singing is human voice following the contours of a melody ("The hills are alive...", etc.) Rapping is talking, delivered in a monotone. It ain't music, it has nothing to do with music, no matter how politically IN-correct it is to say this.

There. I said it. Ah dunno what the chances are of this post being blocked or censored...
Yes, a birthday present for everybody.  A dwarf planet greeting us with a heart emblazoned on its surface or is it a butterfly with one slightly fragile wing?  lol, lol!  Oh, how we all need this!

Finally. A small sliver of sanity has crept in from the back door. The IMF is saying what the Greeks elected a new government in January to scream from the rooftops. They need to write down part of the debt.

The U.S. has a controlling interest in the IMF and effective veto power - that is why this is finally happening. The U.S. also has multiple crises around the world to manage and expected Germany to step up and be the leader of Europe, not just a financial overlord, but Merkel failed because she's beholden only to the banks. The German goal is regime change in Athens; it should happen in Berlin instead.
The problem is that debt forgiveness won't help. In a few years, the debt will be back. The problem is the Greek culture, and neither soft love nor tough love  can save Greece. Time to give up.

So, the IMF reported to the EU finance and the political leaders before they negotiated on Saturday and Sunday, respectively, that Greece could not re-pay the loans and continued austerity could make the loans even harder to repay by decreasing GDP so the loans would become 200% of GDP in two years.

That makes even more clear that Germany's intent was to punish Greece, not to help it.

The Greeks lied to get into the EURO&EU. They won't collect taxes from their Oligarchs & others also; they retired in their 50s not 67 like Germany. Their potential sugar daddy in Moscow has no extra funds to give them due to his escapades in the Ukraine & lower oil revenues.
If the Greeks behave & meet EU's requirements for a year or more, then perhaps debt forgiveness & extending payment due dates could be done.
I agree with you but please learn the difference between "its" and "it's". I usually stop reading when I see a blooper tike this.

The EU holds out Spain as a success story for their kind of "solidarity= growth" and it hasn't worked in Spain where the unemployment level is only reduced by the number of young Spainards who have left the country to find employment and a better life.  Speaking to a History teacher(former) who was fired when the Spanish educational system greatly enlarged the permissible number of students  in one class and who then migrated around Europe with his young wife looking for work.  He relates that every public service sector did the same, nurses, doctors, bus drivers, etc.  If Greece goes down, so will the E.U. as it is composed of today.  Greece is just one country that stood up to the money-lenders, others suffer as well.
Geopolitical  reasons are not a reason, since your Master-Putin- has little money to subsidize Greece due to his escapades in Ukraine & lower oil prices.

Merkel and the EU knew Greece would be unable to service their debt when the desperate Greeks accepted the first payout. They were waiting for Greece to fail so that they can demand Greek assets. Are countries to fear economic recessions moving forward because they will be bought up if they can't make their payments to the banks? It is also very distressing to know that Merkel tightened the terms of the agreement and would not let Greece accept the better terms offered the week before. And this is coming from a country who was able to rebuild itself after being generously granted debt relief in 1953 under the London Debt Relief Program. Greeks may have been indulgent in the past but they did not cause a world war that Greece had to rebuild itself from.

Note the IMF (with no objection from ECB currently constricting liquidity to Greece) demand EU taxpayers, including Greeks, foot the bill to fully guarantee interest income for IMF, ECB and private creditors. Rules have already been broken to load more debt on Greek taxpayers, in the first place. If Greece exited the euro, EU taxpayers would take a one-time loss, along with the ECB, IMF and private creditors. If the precedent is set, then it may be repeated for other countries.

Hypocrisy is the compliment vice pays to virtue - Francois de La Rochefoucauld

No payments for 30 years?

Talk about burdening your children's children!
For once I am glad the IMF is in on the conversation for just this reason. The US has by far the most votes in the IMF and this is, as you write, clearly Washington speaking.

Unlike the other entities taking part in the negotiations, IMF has some American money and American employees and is willing to push the the American view into the discussion whether the European politicians like it or not.
It's clear that key leaders in Europe don't understand economics.  You can destroy someone's economy, or you can ask them to pay off a loan, but you can't do both at the same time. Duh.

It is best for Greece not to pass the measures mandated by EU.  The country already owes more than $400bln, and is taking on another $80bln more debt.  There is no hope for the future generation of Greeks.  Pensioners and people receiving government assistance should take the pain in the next few years so that the younger generation can have a future,

For Germany the Euro was a devaluation of its currency, as the old Deutsche Mark had a higher value. This has made Germany's products cheaper on world markets, enabled it to remain first or second as a global exporter, and at the same time, the Euro by being over-valued for the rest of Europe, has made Germany's competitors' products more expensive, crushed their exports, and enabled Germany to act superior as if this were all due to its own virtue, rather than to a mere devaluation for them, and an over-valuation for the rest of Euro-zone members.

With this dose of refreshing honesty, I think the writing is on the wall and the euro's days are numbered. Let Germany keep the euro. The rest of Europe can live very well without it. The demise is entirely on Germany's head.

One way is if most of the money you lend me comes back to you in the form of interest payments for that loan, and then I still owe you the principle of the loan.  I'm sure financial elites are far more creative than me and can come up with many others.
